story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Actor has become somewhat notorious for his accidental leaking&nbspof Marvel spoilersMark Ruffalo has revealed how Marvel reacted after his now-legendary Facebook Live leak of the premiere of&nbspThor: Ragnarok.&nbspThe actor appeared on&nbspThe Graham Norton Show&nbspwhere he discussed his new film,&nbspDark Waters,&nbspbut also his now-notorious habit of accidentally leaking film spoilers.&nbspBack in 2017, Ruffalo was attending the&nbspThor premiere when he took part in a backstage Facebook Live broadcast to fans before the film began, under instructions from the film’s publicity team.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesUnfortunately, he didn’t turn off the livestream before sitting down to watch the movie, and ended up broadcasting the first 20 minutes of the film to thousands of people.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Marvel films – ranked worst to best Show all 23Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.23. Iron Man 2 barely holds together. Rather than act as a straight sequel to the surprisingly successful Iron Man, Marvel Studios decided to overstuff the film with universe-building references (Black Widow, Nick Fury and SHIELD’s Agent Coulson all make appearances) and two-dimensional villains (played by Sam Rockwell and Mickey Rourke). The result is a film without any direction that serves as a Trojan horse set-up for the Avengers.22. When the Thor franchise lost its director Kenneth Branagh between the first and second films, it also had to kiss goodbye to the Shakespearean theatrics that had lent it a sense of goofy charm. Directed by Game of Thrones’s Alan Taylor, The Dark World prioritises its VFX effects above all else. It’s a dull affair: Christopher Eccleston’s Malekith is (by far) Marvel’s worst villain, being a pile of prosthetics with zero personality, while Chris Hemsworth’s Thor completes one of the most unrealistic London Tube journeys in all of cinematic history.21. Edward Norton’s version of the smashing Hulk often gets forgotten by Marvel fans – and for good reason. Whereas Mark Ruffalo’s bumbling interpretation of the character has a gravitational charm, Norton’s moping monster is void of any charisma. With Liv Tyler phoning in her performance as love interest, Betty Ross, the film falls emotionally flat and serves only as a by-the-numbers origins story.423 Avengers: Age of Ultron20. Just in case we’d forgotten that the Disney corporation is an all-consuming titan that owns half of Hollywood, the sequel to 2012’s Avengers decided to sneak in a little corporate synergy: when Iron Man accidentally creates a sentient robot (voiced by James Spader) who decides the earth’s only salvation is through the destruction of humanity, he announces his grim plans with accompaniment of a little citation of the classic “I’ve Got No Strings” from 1940’s Pinocchio. It’s a moment that exemplifies how Ultron feels like a cold, calculated operation from Marvel Studios. It’s merely tick list of obligations to move us on to the next chapter of the MCU.19. Although Kenneth Branagh’s introductory outing for Marvel’s God of Thunder fared perfectly well on release, it’s suffered massively from the MCU’s dramatic sense of progression over the years. Certainly, Tom Hiddleston’s Loki is a strong, well-crafted character right out of the gate, and his plot against his adoptive father (Anthony Hopkins) is delightfully heightened. Yet, it arguably took until Thor: Ragnarok for Chris Hemsworth’s hero to develop much sense of character beyond the initial “fish out of water” trope.18. A self-centred wealthy white man ventures to a distant land and realises his superhero potential – sound familiar? That’s because Doctor Strange and Iron Man are basically the same story, except one uses magic and the other explosives. Benedict Cumberbatch’s Marveldebut impresses with kaleidoscope visuals but lacks the heart of Robert Downey Jr’s hero, leading to a film that wastes the talents of both Tilda Swinton and Mads Mikkelsen. 723 s of the Galaxy Vol 217. The first s of the Galaxy was a risky Star Wars-inspired romp through space, following a bunch of a-holes who form an unlikely familiar bond. For the second film, James Gunn decided to turn everything up to 11, cramming half a dozen interweaving storylines, leading to Chris Pratt’s gaunt Star Lord getting side-lined. The sequel did, however, introduce the now beloved line “I’m Mary Poppins, y’all”, shouted by Yondu as he gracefully falls from the sky. A wonderfully comedic moment in a film that misses on another half-dozen punches.16. Marvel’s first crossover film was an unparalleled cinematic event – one that arguably changed Hollywood filmmaking forever, now that every major studio seems to be attempting the “shared universe” approach to franchises. Although the MCU has refined the template since, The Avengers still established the focus on humour, character, and heart that would come to define the success story of Marvel Studios. It’s a blockbuster that feels large on all fronts, delivering thrills not only in the “Battle of New York” finale, but in the creation of a team of characters that feel perfectly balanced and complementary.15. Despite Captain America: Civil War (AKA Avengers 2.5) featuring Iron Man, Black Widow, and Ant-Man (as well as introducing Black Panther and Spider-Man), the film remains first and foremost about Captain America. And that’s perhaps why the stuffed blockbuster works – were it not for a central focus, Civil War could have fallen into the trappings of other Marvel sequels in being too convoluted. The Russo Brothers also direct one of the best actions scenes in Marvel history so far, the airport scene, which looks as if it leapt straight out of a comic book.1023 Ant-Man and the Wasp14. While the first Ant Man was a mirror image of its star Paul Rudd, essentially delivering a studio comedy dressed in dex, the second found a new trick up its sleeve in the form of Evangeline Lilly’s Hope van Dyne – a smart, capable female hero who didn’t simply exist to serve as a caretaker for the male characters.13. What comes after the end? It’s the question that was hanging over the Marvel Cinematic Universe ever since the release of Avengers: Endgame was sold to us as the ultimate, cumulative chapter in a series of 22 interconnected films. And yet, while Far From Home is distinctly mid-level Marvel fare, there’s a lot to be said for the fact it isn’t crushed under the weight of its own ambitions. It feels comfortably like the end of a chapter, the beginning of a new one, an epilogue, and a palate cleanser all at once. It also works perfectly well as a film about Spider-Man.12. Ant-Man should not have worked as a film. Just look at the title! Ridiculous to think a movie about a man with ant powers should work – let alone be a blockbuster success and part of the biggest cinematic universe going. Yet, despite production problems (Edgar Wright was initially meant to helm the film), Peyton Reed directs this hilarious heist film with aplomb, taking the Marvel world a little less seriously than others. 11. Marvel redefined cinematic narratives once more in 2018, creating a single culmination to a decade’s worth of films. While it plays as total nonsense to anyone who’s a newcomer to the franchise (if that’s possible), it was, for fans, an unmatched emotional release. The Russo brothers faced the monumental task of making each crossover – from the s of the Galaxy to the kingdom of Wakanda – work in a way that feels natural, while also ushering the MCU’s biggest villain, Thanos, into centre stage. Epic both in its sense of scale and stakes, Infinity War also stages one of the most memorable finales in blockbuster history.10. With or without the beard, Steve Rogers aka Captain America has now become the brooding centre of the Avengers, but there was once a time when he was all about the old-fashioned heroics. Director Joe Johnston stayed true to the film’s 1940s setting in a film that embraces that pulpiness of early comic book history, as Steve punches Nazis and romances military officer Peggy Carter (Hayley Atwell), although her character is thankfully never relegated to the role of damsel in distress.9. Despite centring on a super-powered American nationalist, the Captain America trilogy has the most consistent quality in the MCU. Its crowning moment comes with The Winter Soldier – an adrenaline-fuelled conspiracy thriller that features a spectacular twist and provokes questions regarding modern day surveillance. However, given The Russo Brothers root the rest of the movie in realism, the bombastic CGI-heavy ending is a little ridiculous. 8. Brie Larson gives a superpowered performance as Carol Danvers, the actor playing a hero that's both relatable and aspirational, strong but vulnerable. While Captain Marvel may not revolutionise the studio’s formula, the superhero's debut outing provides a platform to show off her Thanos-annihilating powers.  Thanks to a smart script, it also offers some of the very best character development in the MCU.7. While Spider-Man’s miraculous arrival in the MCU came with Captain America: Civil War, it was not until Homecoming that we truly got to know Peter Parker. Tom Holland’s incarnation swings past Andrew Garfield’s version, thanks to the film’s lower-stakes high school story allowing for intimate moments with the character. Along with including some great comic performances (Jacob Batalon as Ned stands out), Michael Keaton’s Vulture makes for a terrifying villain, and the twist is superbly done.6. While isive among Marvel fans, Shane Black’s superhero outing – with the writerdirector’s sharp, stinging dialogue – brings Tony Stark's story arc to an end (or what should have been its end) with humour and heart aplenty. As Robert Downey Jr’s genius, billionaire philanthropist deals with PTSD and struggles with his robotic creations, we see an actor giving his all. While Civil War and the Avengers films dragged him back into action, fingers are crossed Avengers: Endgame will give the character a similar emotionally satisfying send-off.5. It’s a film that’s hard to place within the MCU canon, simply because the majority of its emotional pay-offs only work due to the groundwork laid by over a decade of filmmaking. Avengers: Endgame is less about inidual storytelling and so much more about the collective experience of cinema itself. This exists to be consumed in the dark, surrounded by loved ones, as  you all cheer, gasp, and cry in unison. The fan service at work may, at times, feel a little outrageous in just how bold it feels, but Endgame earns the right to indulge. This, above all, is a celebration of these movies and their impact on the world. 4. Completely transforming the Thor franchise in a single, effortless move, director Taika Waititi injected new energy into the MCU. Ragnarok is perfectly balanced both as a standard Marvel movie, with all the right heroics and world-building intact, and as a work belonging exclusively to Waititi, filled with the humour and charm he’d previously displayed in What We Do in the Shadows and Hunt for the Wilderpeople. By finding a way to incorporate inidual voices into its massive franchise machine, Marvel found the secret to true long-term success.3. Where it all started. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'It's the first time a lunar sample has been studied like this,' says researcherA new technique could provide major insights into the Moon's surface, the scientists behind it have said.The approach – which should allow researchers to find entirely new breakthroughs in pieces of lunar rock that are nearly 50 years old – involves analysing the rocks at the most minute level, in the hope of learning about the Moon.It could also help future astronauts who Nasa hopes can live on the Moon's surface in a lunar base, by allowing them to find important materials in the ground.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesWhen the last astronauts arrived on the Moon in 1972, they brought back important samples, like those who went before them. They were to be the last pieces of the lunar surface to come back to Earth, since humanity has not been back in the nearly 50 years since.That means that those remaining samples are especially precious since they are limited and can not be easily replaced. They can also be profoundly illuminating, offering us our only chance to get close to rock taken from a whole separate world.Created with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. It's the first time a lunar sample has been studied like this. We're using a technique many geologists haven't even heard of.Scientists to make air out of lunar dust amid plans to live on MoonAs researchers make use of the new technique, they expect to find a vast set of new information about the lunar surface.We can apply this technique to samples no one has studied, Philipp Heck, a curator at the Field Museum, associate professor at the University of Chicago, and co-author of the paper, adds. You're almost guaranteed to find something new or unexpected.This technique has such high sensitivity and resolution, you find things you wouldn't find otherwise and only use up a small bit of the sample.The technique is called atom probe tomography, and involves incredibly precise manipulation of inidual grains. It has previously been used in industrial processes – but the new breakthrough has come in turning it for the first time to lunar samples.It works something like nanocarpentry, said Professor Heck: like a carpenter shapes wood, we do it at the nanoscale to minerals.The sample is placed inside a special probe and then shot with a laser that knocks off inidual atoms, which then fall onto a special plate. Researchers can examine those elements by timing how long they take to hit the detector – since heavier ones take longer – and so the type of atom can be worked out.It has already helped researchers see the weathering and materials that can be found inside the lunar soil. That in turn could help future astronauts as they move to live on the Moon, since they could survive by taking resources out of that dust.The researchers now hope they can get hold of samples from elsewhere on the Moon, and elsewhere in space, to allow them to better understand the makeup of the worlds that surround us. They compare our current understanding to analysing Earth using only one mountain range – to get a fuller grasp, they will need to examine a variety of terrains across the solar system.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: home office immigration detention phone outage deportation flight legal advice
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘I can’t get hold of my solicitor – the only chance of getting out of here... It feels like I’m losing my mind’Ministers have admitted a mobile phone outage at removal centres has prevented people from accessing legal&nbspservices to challenge their deportation, days before a charter flight is set to leave the UK.The Home Office has been forced to admit it has known about the issue affecting detainees’ mobile phone signals in detention centres near Heathrow airport since 13 January, but took 23 days to begin providing detainees with working sim&nbspcards – during which it pressed ahead with charter flights to Ghana, Nigeria and France.Campaigners accused the government of removing people from the country without giving them their lawful right to legal advice and assistance during&nbspthe “crucial window” leading up to the removal flights.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPeople who are due to be deported on a charter flight to Jamaica on Tuesday told The Independent that as a result of the outage, they had struggled to communicate with their solicitors and send them relevant documents to challenge their removals.Mobile phones provided by the Home Office at the outset of detention are the principal means by which detainees are able to access legal assistance, contact their solicitors and stay in touch with their families.Government told to review deportations days before charter flightEchard Bepart-Woollett, 27, who came to Britain when he was eight&nbspand has two British children, said he had been struggling to communicate with his solicitor since the Home Office issued him with deportation orders last week.“I can’t get hold of my solicitor – the only chance of getting out of here. It’s getting mad. It feels like I’m losing my mind. It’s like all communication has been shut down. Everyone is trying to get hold of their solicitor to see what’s going on,” said the Jamaican national.“If they don’t get the paperwork, I can’t go to court, I can’t fight. It’s black and white. You need everything documented and proven, and if I can’t get that out, then I’m f***ed.”Mr Bepart-Woollett’s solicitor, Marina Khan of Duncan Lewis Solicitors, said her client had a strong case&nbspto remain in Britain but that the mobile outages had meant filing submissions to challenge his deportation has taken much longer than normal.“We were trying to contact him every day since he instructed us on 31 January, and it took us until 6 February&nbspto formally take details instructions from him. It’s been awful. His partner was stressing out,” she said.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“I needed to get his documents so that I could send his submissions to the Home Office. I couldn’t send it during office hours because I didn’t receive it in time. The delay was unreasonable.“It’s caused a lot of undue stress and frustration for our client. He’s been totally deprived of contacting his legal representatives and unable to access legal justice and advice from us.”MPs Nadia Whittome and Dawn Butler raise the issue of people on next week’s deportation flight to JamaicaAnother detainee, Reshawn Davis, 30, who came to the UK at the age of 11 and has a British six-month-old baby,&nbspsaid the signal issues were “extremely frustrating”.“People are telling me they’re trying to call me and I don’t see the call. My phone just doesn’t ring. I haven’t spoken to my solicitor directly at all because of the signal. It’s been a huge added stress. I don’t know what’s going on,” he said.“It’s stopping me talking to my family as well. My daughter knows my voice. If I say something over the phone, she’s thinking Daddy’s home. I say her name and she looks up for me. But this signal is preventing me from talking to her.”People facing imminent removal from the UK are entitled to notice periods ranging from three to five days during which it is, by law, vital that they are able to access legal advice and assistance, for example to assess the merits of challenging their removal.Windrush victims given additional two years to apply for compensation‘Home Office is destroying their lives’: Father-of-two to be deportedGovernment told to review deportations days before charter flightBella Sankey, director of Detention Action, which has launched a legal challenge against the Home Office over its alleged failure to provide effective access to legal advice to detainees, said: “An eleventh-hour issuing of sim cards may not be sufficient for those seeking to challenge their removal on Tuesday’s flight. Not to mention the impact on those that have been removed while the signal has been down.&nbsp“This is a partial victory for access to justice but there are many unanswered questions and our legal challenge will proceed.”It comes after a&nbspleaked draft of the&nbspWindrush&nbspLessons Learned&nbspreview stated that ministers should consider ending the practice of deporting people who arrived in the UK as children, prompting calls for the Home Office to put&nbspdeportation flight on hold until the review is published.The Home Office has been approached for comment.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus news live china uk virus symptoms hong kong wuhan latest today
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Follow here for the latest developmentsThe coronavirus is poised to become more deadly than SARS, as the global death toll climbed&nbspto 724.Hong Kong imposed quarantine rules on travellers from mainland China, where the virus claimed 86 lives on Friday – more than any other day since the outbreak began.Meanwhile, a British honeymooner was transferred to a Japanese hospital from the Diamond Princess cruise liner, where nearly 3,700 passengers and crew, including his wife, remain stranded onboard in the port of Yokohama.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPlease allow a moment for the live blog to load.Wuhan residents 'dragged from homes'Five new cases in France are all Britons, minister saysBritish family of four hospitalised in MajorcaVirus claims 86 lives in mainland ChinaA second evacuation flight bringing back Singaporeans and their family members from virus-hit Wuhan in China is expected to arrive on Sunday morning.The city-state evacuated 92 Singaporeans from Wuhan last Thursday, some of whom have since been confirmed as infected. Authorities said they had to leave some passengers behind who were showing symptoms.A flight carrying medical supplies and diagnostic test kits, departed this afternoon for Wuhan, the country's foreign ministry said. Appropriate quarantine arrangements have been made for all of the returnees, it added.Two Britons infected with the virus are thought to have contracted it while in Singapore.The country's authorities are&nbspinvestigating a three-day business meeting held in&nbspa hotel from 20 January&nbspbetween&nbsp94 foreign nationals, France's&nbspdirector general of health, Jerome Salomon, said.Government tells Brighton pupil's parents to ‘self-isolate’ child for 14 days&nbspPublic Health England has told the parents of a pupil in Brighton suburb to self-isolate their child, who reportedly came into contact with a man found to be suffering with the virus on Thursday.Parents whose children attend Portslade Academy were emailed yesterday to inform them of the development by head teacher Mark Poston, Brighton and Hove News reported.“We are working in collaboration with and being guided by the local authority and Public Health England to ensure that we at PACA are acting consistently with the right medical advice, Mr Poston wrote.“Today we have been contacted by a parent of a student at PACA who was contacted by Public Health England as part of their investigation concerning the confirmed case that was reported in the press yesterday.“We have been informed by the parent that they have been advised by Public Health England to self-isolate their child at home for 14 days. If at any point the child is found to be symptomatic we will be notified.Fear more harmful than virus, Singapore PM says after raising alert levelPrime minister Lee Hsien Loong appealed for the public to remain calm, after the alert update&nbspprompted&nbspresidents to clear out supermarket shelves of rice, noodles and toilet paper.Singapore raised its response to orange - the same as during the 2003 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreak, which indicates the virus is severe and passes easily between persons.There is no need to panic. We are not locking down the city or confining everybody to stay at home,the PM&nbspsaid on Saturday. We have ample supplies, so there is no need to stock up with instant noodles, tinned food, or toilet paper, as some people did yesterday.UK to donate £5m to World Health OrganisationThe Department for International Development said the sum would help the WHO prevent the spread of the virus in developing countries,&nbspby supporting them to rapidly identify and care for patients with symptoms.Additional experts funded by UK aid will be deployed to the WHO to help coordinate the international response, the&nbspstatement said.This week, the UN health agency asked the international community for $560m to help their efforts to combat the virus.On Friday, the United States signalled it would donate $100m in foreign aid to help the response in China and other countries.A child is among the five British nationals&nbspwho have contracted the virus in France.They were all staying in the same chalet in a ski resort in Haute-Savoie.The initial case had recently travelled to Singapore, health minister Agnes Buzyn said.British family of four hospitalised in MajorcaA couple and their two children have been admitted to hospital on the Spanish island, after coming into contact with someone suffering from the virus, reports suggest.The father reportedly went to Son Espases hospital in Palma on Thursday to inform them he had been in contact with someone who had contracted the virus and was quarantined there. His wife and two children have now also been admitted.Hong Kong imposes quarantine on travellers from mainland ChinaAmid much public pressure, the region&nbsp– which has 26 confirmed cases –&nbspannounced a mandatory two-week quarantine for those crossing the border from mainland China.Anyone caught flouting the quarantine could be fined and imprisoned.Visitors must go to government-run facilities or self-isolate in hotel rooms, while residents must not leave their homes.Coronavirus death toll set to outstrip SARS as 86 deaths recorded in China&nbspThe virus has now claimed 724 lives, with mainland China seeing its deadliest day yet,&nbspreversing two days of declines and showing the difficulty of predicting the epidemic's peak.Some 774 deaths recorded globally during the 2002-2003 SARS&nbsppandemic, another coronavirus that jumped from animals to humans in China.The number of reported cases of SARS was 8,098, suggesting a far lower transmission rate than the latest coronavirus, but a higher mortality rate.Good morning, this is&nbspThe Independent's&nbsplive coverage of the coronavirus outbreak.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: tv licence bbc blame reputation
story: So the new Government consultation over decriminalising non-payment is long overdue.A compulsory tax made sense in . Punishing non-payers nowadays is absurd.The Beeb will fight all the way. But consider how it has trashed its once-proud reputation:Fundamentally it’s a dinosaur in the Netflix era and irrelevant to many, especially young people raised on YouTube.The Government must be bold. We need a much slimmer BBC to survive and focus on quality TV and radio.But the licence has had its day.BORIS Johnson can only lead the world on climate change with the public on his side and our economy in the front of his mind.The Government churns out random dates in the not-too-distant future by which it demands we all buy electric cars and replace our gas central heating.Yes, the UK is hosting a climate summit this year and it must be ambitious.But do the Tories have a clue about the cost to consumers and the economy  Michael Gove was suspiciously coy.This country is not governed by Greta Thunberg — nor the Marxist wreckers running Extinction Rebellion.The Tories must level with the public and ensure that our global warming efforts BOOST the economy instead of wrecking it.And they will be near-worthless anyway unless the world’s worst polluters, China in particular, follow the example Britain is already setting in slashing emissions.JIHADIST murderers and their supporters should be judged criminally insane and held indefinitely as long as they are a danger.Most villains recognise our civilisation’s definitions of right and wrong.IS do not. Their extreme version of Islam legitimises slaughtering innocent people.Anyone  randomly stabbing ­passers-by or encouraging it would probably be classed as insane and locked away forever. Why not jihadis  The fact they consider their motives rational and noble proves they have lost their minds.Lesser offenders may be deradicalised, though that is a long shot. Others should be kept without time limit in a secure unit, maybe built specically for them.If we treat these religious madmen like “ordinary” murderers — with a stretch in a normal prison — we will keep making the same disastrous mistakes. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ban disel giant leap in the dark
story: The lack of joined-up thinking is depressing.Only . per cent of new motors sold in the UK are electric. Which is not surprising when they are at least £, more than the petrol equivalent and most have woeful mileage ranges.Yet the Government, desperate to advertise its green credentials, blithely announces a ban on new petrol, diesel and even hybrid cars in just  years.But it’s not a concrete, costed plan . . . just a giant leap in the dark.How does it intend to totally re-equip Britain for roadside charging — or fund it while its multi-billion pound fuel duty income withers away to nothing How will people afford these cars unless prices plummet, which experts say is unlikely in the foreseeable future  And why is the Government poised to axe the subsidies that help us to buy We don’t in principle think taxpayers should fund anyone’s new motor. But why remove buyers’ sole financial incentive now, when the industry badly needs a jump-start The Government is hopping on a bandwagon without considering the consequences, like Labour  years ago when it urged everyone to buy diesels.Meanwhile councils are already brainlessly instigating city centre bans or fines on all but the tiny number of zero-emission vehicles currently on the road.Who can blame motorists for being confused and angry  Many will happily drive more eco-friendly cars once they are viable and affordable.But this is all stick and no carrot.BRITAIN should not be proudly flying our flag for Prince Andrew’s birthday. It is a grotesque gesture in the circumstances.Maybe his long, close friendship with Jeffrey Epstein — a jailed paedophile, pimp and sex trafficker of under-age girls — was entirely innocent.But he has still been sacked from Royal duties and accused of ignoring FBI demands to question him.Epstein’s victims are adamant Andrew mustto the US.What an insult to themTown Halls raise the Union Jack to honour him instead.WHEN it comes to helping the disabled, Boris Johnson can put his money where his mouth is right now.We are delighted to see the PM ask every Cabinet minister to find ways their department can contribute to his new National Disability Strategy.But there’s a £million black hole in funding for social care for families with disabled kids which Sajid Javid’s Budget on March  should fill. Our Give It Back campaign has highlighted it.Turn warm words into action, PM.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tension reporters no10 system snapped
story: As Sun readers know, there are important issues at the moment, from anti-terrorism laws, to HS, to post-Brexit Britain’s trading prospects. What is the future of the BBC  Should China build our telecoms network Seldom has the political news agenda been so packed. But what is the story gaining traction at Westminster  For the latest, let’s go straight to our correspondent outside  Downing Street - who, oh dear, is stomping away in protest like Dick Emery’s Honky Tonks, having just had a blazing row with Boris Johnson’s media strategist.Yes, the big story, crazily, is the stand-off between political journalists and the PM’s media advisers. The reporters, hardly the most delicate bunch of dahlias, are wailing that the Government is being beastly to them.In the blue corner we have Downing Street’s press officers who, in an unusual interpretation of the Trade Description Act, are refusing to speak to the Press. When newspapers write about themselves, readers are entitled to roll their eyes.Political news, like the mass-production of pork bangers, is a manufacturing process best conducted away from the view of consumers. Not unless you want to turn the whole country vegan.I’ve been in newspapers since the mid-s, much of the time at Westminster, and have met drunkards, liars, gropers, cheats — and that was just the religious-affairs writers. Don’t let’s pretend journalism or politics attracts innocent hayseeds. Which makes the over-reacting on both sides of the ide in recent days so ridiculous.Creative tension between reporters and politicians’ media handlers is a healthy thing, but the system has suddenly snapped. This follows a general election in which it sometimes felt as though the media, particularly broadcasters, niggled Boris Johnson more effectively than Jeremy Corbyn did.When Boris won a thumping majority, his aides may have thought: “Right, now we can exact revenge on our media tormentors.” If so, they are foolish and unprofessional.First, they started mucking about with the daily briefings to the Westminster press lobby, the club of accredited journalists who report on politics.Then, on Monday, they tried to bar some members of that lobby from a briefing by David Frost, Boris’s main adviser on the European trade negotiations. Some scribes were told they could attend, others were told they were barred.Downing Street claimed that the briefing was too specialised for general politics writers to appreciate. The reporters took a dferent view.They reckoned Downing Street strategist Dominic Cummings and his sidekick Lee Cain were trying to ide and rule, and to winnow out the journalistic troublemakers. In a rare moment of solidarity among hacks, the newshounds upped and left. Walkout!This squabble is now headline news. Urgent questions were raised in the Commons and many papers and broadcasters are protesting that the Government is trying to censor the free Press in a “sinister” way.They compare this tactic to Donald Trump’s denunciation of mainstream US media for spreading “fake news” . Sir Keir Starmer, would-be leader of the Labour Party, joined the outcry, siding with the journalists. We could have done without that slippery little bit of opportunism.The same Starmer boasted recently that he would refuse to talk to reporters from The Sun, presumably because this paper is not in his pocket.Attempts to neutralise awkward reporters are not exactly new. During the  election, as a scurvy political sketch writer, I was locked out of a Tony Blair campaign event in The Wrekin.Gordon Brown’s people stopped me attending a media event with the president of South Africa.Tory party cronies barred me from witnessing a leadership debate between David Cameron and David Davis in . In the last election, non-sympathetic journalists were not given access to Jeremy Corbyn’s battle bus. Mind you, we were lucky. As one Leftie reporter told me: “You couldn’t get on Corbyn’s bus but I couldn’t get OFF it!”Despite some of those historic precedents, the current “lobby war” is more problematic because it looks more concerted and because it comes at a time when traditional news sources are under challenge from the internet.Online news sites can be shady and unreliable. Traditional lobby journalists, for all their faults, are at least reasonably accountable.Both sides should cool it. The lobby should admit that its clique is unacceptably clubby for st-century politics. And Boris’s henchmen should drop the macho posturing. Why are they picking this fight at a time when the Government is so popular  Never a better time for it, they might say. They want to show who’s boss.You could compare their aggression to that of an inmate who on arrival in prison butts the first guy he meets in order to show other prisoners he’s a tough guy. In my experience, journalists respond badly to this approach.Look at the damage Tony Blair’s thuggish spokesman Alastair Campbell did to the government he served.It is not beyond the wit of ministers to palm favourable stories to selected journaliststhey so wish. But the central media unit at No should remember — as they have repeatedly told us — that they are “the people’s Government” and not merely the servants of Boris Johnson.Their juicy salaries come from the taxpayer and the taxpayer does not expect them to abuse their privileged position.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new homes 30 per cent cheaper
story: Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick’s “First Homes” plan will take landowners’ profits to pay for a discount of  per cent.The move, aimed at the lower paid who are battling to save to buy a home, will lop an average of £, off the asking price of a typical home.And the discount will be locked in to the ­property’s price to ensure it is sold on at well below the usual asking price, to help the first-time buyers of the future.As well as locals, ­forces’ veterans will be prioritised for the house purchases along with front-line workers such as cops, nurses, prison officers and teachers.The plan, a Tory manesto promise, is the first in a major drive by Boris Johnson’s government to get more young people on the property ladder and solve Britain’s chronic housing crisis.Dubbing the plan “genuinely le-changing”, Mr Jenrick said: “Many who are seeking to buy their own home in their local areas have been forced out due to rising prices.“A proportion of new homes will be made available at a  per cent market discount, turning the dial on the dream of home ownership.”THE new “First Homes” plan could be a game-changer for young people priced out of owning property.We wouldn’t normally back a state scheme to carve off developers’ profits to subsidise homes.But the market has failed a generation, rapid action is needed and builders’ takings are vast.Soaring prices and Help To Buy sent their margins into orbit.The giants have squeezed out small rivals and release new builds slowly to keep prices up. Their bosses make mind-boggling salaries.It’s payback time.Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick’s imaginative plan will cut prices for local first-time buyers by a third —  a huge dference.But the Government must ensure hundreds of thousands of affordable homes get built this way.Previous over-hyped initiatives have produced derisory numbers.Long-term we need a bonfire of planning restrictions,  more developers able to compete and far more houses built.Campaigners warned the new homes must not come at the expense of losing new social housing.Polly Neate, boss of Shelter, said: “The country desperately needs more low-cost homes which are genuinely affordable to those people struggling at the sharp end of the housing crisis.“But, instead of offering a route to building additional low cost homes, this policy simply puts at risk the social homes currently being built.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: praise british coast people
story: But rarely in all the debate about what our future now holds do you hear about the wonders of our coastline — which, when you think we have more than , miles of it, doesn’t feel right.Presenting Our Coast with Mehreen Baig, I’ve seen just how beautul it is, and how many brilliant people live their lives there.They are a special breed of unsung heroes.It can be tough for sure, in places the rest of us used to holiday — places we profess to love, often without actually doing that much to nurture.There are challenges in many coastal communities, and they definitely need the money politicians of all stripes have promised them.But I’ve also been struck by how hard they’re working to turn things around themselves. There is often hope where we may first see ­dficulty. You just have to look a bit harder sometimes.In Portpatrick, at Scotland’s bottom left corner, the harbour had fallen into miserable disrepair. A plan was hatched to stop the rot.A local hero organised a share issue for locals to raise the money to buy the harbour and restore the buildings around it. The village now has its pecker up again and the future looks bright.It’s a similar story on Anglesey. At Halen Mon a thriving family business draws water out of the Menai Strait, harvests the salt and sells it all over the world.Near there I met a woman called Sian Sykes who cared about those waters so much she paddle-boarded  miles around Anglesey picking out the plastic.Asthat wasn’t enough, she then paddled the whole coast of Wales doing exactly the same.But my favourite character round there is no longer with us. On the very western tip of Holy Island off Anglesey’s west coast, there is the South Stack lighthouse. It’s been saving sailors from watery deaths since .A hundred years ago, John Jones was its keeper and it was his great granddaughter Denise Shaw who took me up to the top of it.Denise showed me a photograph of her great-grandad sporting a magnicent moustache the seagulls must have coveted for their nests.He was no loner, though. Denise remembers her mum saying old great-gramps was a bit of a ladies’ man.And what a chat-up line he had at his disposal: “Do you want to come back to my place to see how bright my light is ”All four of the areas we’ve looked at for this series of Our Coast are around the Irish Sea. I had a brilliant time at Belfast docks where I joined the harbour pilots, whose work astounded me.It’s their job to bring the giant ships safely into port.I sort of assumed they did this by chugging out to meet them, lighting up a sign saying, “follow me” and gently leading them to their berths.Far from it. Round the clock, all year round, whatever the weather, they race out several miles to pull up alongside these huge vessels.Incredibly, a rope ladder is dropped over the side for the pilots to clamber aboard, make their way to the bridge, take over the controls and steer these monsters into tight spaces on the docks.The ship I boarded with them, somewhat terried, was carrying grain from Romania.As my man took the helm I asked the Polish skipper which country had the best harbour pilots. “You do,” he said, with feeling.Back across the Irish Sea, in Formby, north of Liverpool, I met Mike McComb in the £million place he’s built himself a stone’s throw from the sea.He has more bedrooms, bathrooms and children than I could count .His fortune could have bought him a lavish home anywhere in the world. But it was up here, along the endless beach, that back in the day he and his mates would come on their bikes from their tiny homes in Bootle.So, he tells me as we stand on the beach, lashed by rain and wind, you can keep St Tropez or Malibu. This coast, his coast, is where he’ll stay.The sea seems to be a magnet for the most memorable people, from Grace the crane engineer in Belfast Docks who played rugby for Ireland in three rugby world cups, to Sandy the tattooed pagan near Stranraer who says the sea’s our mother, and the Bulgarian dissident I chanced upon sitting in a hot tub ­surveying Liverpool from the deck of the Queen Mary .My grandad used to tell me that when you put your toe in the sea you’re connected with the whole world.With that in mind, I’ve enjoyed many a paddle this summer reflecting on the power and history of what our island nation is all about.And I urge you to do it, too. After all, it’s pretty easy. Britain’s most landlocked place — Coton in the Elms in Derbyshire — is just  miles from the coast. So none of us is more than a couple of hours away from the sea.There’s never been a more relevant time to get out to the edges and see the soul of this country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Coronavirus has now been confirmed in  countries, and took the lives of  people on Friday alone.Japan announced its first national to die from the virus putting the global death toll just  behind the  fatalities recorded during the SARS epidemic of -.Follow our live blog below for all the latest updates...Hong Kong has imposed a two-week quarantine for anyone ing form mainland China as Hong Kong officials scramble to contain the virus.Anyone visiting from the region must isolate themselves in hotel rooms or government-run centres.Anyone who ignores the rule could be slapped with a fine or even a prison sentence.The death toll has now risen to  with more than , cases globally after the virus appeared in the Chinese city of Wuhan.Professor John Edmunds, from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said modelling showed there were “ten times more cases than have been reported – or even more. “And none of the tests is going to be  per cent sensitive so it is not unusual to only capture maybe  per cent of the cases#.The professor added: #[Coronavirus] is a mild disease that might be missedsomebody doesn’t seek healthcare,” he said.“And none of the tests is going to be  per cent sensitive so it is not unusual to only capture maybe  per cent of the cases.” “When there are very large numbers of cases it becomes very hard to confirm them all just because of manpower. title: jihadi bride shamima begum loses legal bid citizenship
story: The former East London schoolgirl fled to join ISIS in Syria in  before begging to be allowed tohome last year.Begum and two school friends, all aged  and  from Bethnal Green Academy in East London, left the UK to join the terror group.She married Dutch ISIS convert Yago Riedijk  days after arriving in the country, with her pals also reportedly marrying foreign IS fighters.The teenager was later tracked down, nine months pregnant, in a Syrian refugee camp in February . The baby died weeks later shortly after his birth.In an interview with Sky News, she claimed that all she did while living in the so-called caliphate was “make babies” – and pleaded to be allowed tohome.She added her mental health is suffering and she hated ISIS following the deaths of her three children - a one-year-old girl, a three-month-old boy and her newborn baby.Then Home Secretary Sajid Javid stripped her of her British citizenship later that month, a decision Ms Begums lawyers argued was unlawful as it left her statelessLast year, Ms Begum took legal action against the Home Office at the High Court.But a judgement by the Special Immigration Appeals Commissiontoday found against Begum, now .Judge Doron Blum, announcing the decision of the tribunal, said that the move did not breach the Home Offices extraterritorial human rights policy by exposing Ms Begum to a real risk of death or inhuman or degrading treatment.Begum will now appeal against the decision.Her lawyers alleged she has been unable to mount a “fair and effective” legal challenge and was at risk of “death, inhuman or degrading treatment”.It is claimedshe is forced to go to Bangladesh - her parents country of origin - she could be hanged.But the court heard there was no evidence she had ever visited Bangladesh or applied for citizenship there.Ms Begums solicitor, Daniel Furner said the ruling will be hard to explain to her.He said: The logic of the decision will appear baffling, accepting as it does the key underlying factual assessments of extreme danger and extreme unfairness and yet declining to provide any legal remedy.A Home Office spokeswoman said: The Government welcomes the judgement of the Special Immigration Appeals Commission on these preliminary issues.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: orangutan hand save man snakes
story: The gentle creature appears to be leaning down and offering a helping hand to the man who had been in the muddy river searching for snakes - many of which pose a threat to primates.The striking pictures were taken in a conservation forest area in Borneo, where the endangered species are protected from hunters.Amateur photographer Anil Prabhakar, from Indonesia, had been out trekking with friends in the area while on safari, when he spotted the touching encounter taking place.He later found out that the unnamed man worked for the Borneo Orangutan Survival Foundation, a non-profit organisation aimed at protecting the endangered species.The worker, submerged up to his chest in the water, had been clearing away snakes from the area to help keep the orangutans safe before his inquisitive animal friend interrupted him.Mr Prabhakar revealed the worker actually ended up refusing the orangutans hand after the camera caught the incredible moment in a picture, because its a wild animal.He said: Someone told him there was a snake in the river. The warden went there and cleared the bushes.”An orangutan came to the banks and was watching what he was doing. He then came closer and gave his hand.”The warden just moved away. I asked him why later and he said, Its a wild animal, not one we are familiar with.”But they are to protect them.The Borneo Orangutan Survival Foundation is an Indonesian non-profit organisation founded in .It is “dedicated to the conservation of the Bornean orangutan and its habitat”, working in cooperation with local communities, the Indonesian Ministry of Forestry and international partner organisations.The foundation, which has  members of staff, is currently taking care of almost  orangutans.The website says: As one of our closest living relatives orangutans are highly intelligent, sentient beings.”They are an iconic species of Indonesia and an important umbrella species.By protecting orangutans in their natural habitat, a whole plethora of other flora and fauna are also protected. Protecting their forest habitat is as important to humans as much as it is to wildle.

title: jeremy corbyn wont give evidence at review into labour partys worst defeat in 85 years
story: The Labour boss is not giving evidence to the inquiry into what went wrong, which is expected to slam his woeful strategy.Party insiders said the report will find that voters were horried by Mr Corbyn’s alleged links with terrorists like the IRA.While it will also find that Labour “totally lost” the online election battle with the Tories, who managed to get their messages picked up widely on sites like Facebook.The devastating report is expected to be released on April  - the day before the winner of the Labour leadership battle is announced.A Labour source said: “We want it to be the first thing in the new leader’s in-tray”.The inquiry, led by Ed Miliband, is looking into why Labour suffered their worst defeat since .The team has been talking to former MPs who lost their seats, Labour frontbenchers, advisers and activists about where it all went wrong. But bizarrely, Mr Corbyn is not planning to speak to the body about the landslide defeat.One party insider said the report will show that voters were furious at Mr Corbyn and his allies for patronising them.The source said: “Voters wanted a hand up not a hand out by middle class do-gooders.“The defeat was a massive surprise for many activists in groups like Momentum. They didn’t see it coming.“There is a lot of anger from the left over why we did not adopt a more defensive strategy.”The inquiry will warn that Labour desperately needs to rebuild in Scotland, where the now only have one MP, to stand a chance of winning power ever again.The source said: “We can’t win without Scotland. We would have to win Jacob Rees-Mogg’s seat of North East Somerset to get a majority without Scotland.”

title: kirk douglas was the one and only spartacus and he had balls of steel
story: When Kirk came into the world, the Battle of the Somme was still raging and Sir Ernest Shackleton — my own hero — was fighting to save his men on a doomed Antarctic expedition.At , Kirk’s death was not unexpected. But it saddened us all because it felt like this incredible human being would go on for ever.He headed the Douglas dynasty with a zest for le that put the rest of us to shame and was one of our final links to Hollywood’s golden age.Long before actors ostentatiously wore their hearts on their sleeves and made self-aggrandising speeches about the latest trendy cause, Kirk determinedly set out to do the right thing, regardless of any impact on his career.In the Fties, at the height of the Cold War, he stood up to a paranoid US government that considered anyone to the left of Genghis Khan a Soviet sympathiser.The McCarthy witchhunts ruined careers and wrecked lives, but Kirk dug in his heels and hired blacklisted writer Dalton Trumbo to work on Spartacus, which would become Kirk’s most famous movie.That took balls of steel.Kirk gave millions to charity and was a US Goodwill Ambassador, receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Jimmy Carter in .He experienced heartache with the death of his son Eric from an overdose and the jailing of grandson Cameron for drug offences.But even a near-fatal helicopter crash and a stroke couldn’t defeat Kirk.His son Michael — a superstar in his own right, of course — told me last year his dad worked out almost every day with a personal trainer and remained as sharp as a tack, keeping the whole extended family on their toes.I was lucky enough to interview Kirk back in my days with TV-am.The Beeb would fly them over from LA and put them up in a posh hotel.All we could offer was a hearty breakfast, plus the chance to talk about themselves and their new project for as long as they liked.There were no pesky managers and PRs to go through.Bette Davis, Burt Lancaster, Lauren Bacall and Sammy Davis Jnr all popped into our studio at the crack of sparrows, staying for the duration of the show.Kirk was here in , promoting Dance With The Devil, a racy novel that bore a passing resemblance to his extraordinary le story.After his Jewish parents escaped persecution in Russia, Kirk was born and raised in a poor area of New York.It is a real rags-to-riches tale. His dad actually worked as a rag-and-bone man.Kirk never forgot where he came from, which is perhaps why he became a champion for justice and a fairer society.He was a delight that morning and even laughed when the crew declared, “I’m Spartacus”, one after another in his honour — though he must have seen it done hundreds of times before.He was a also a much-loved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather.The Douglas clan will be in mourning but they can celebrate a le well lived.This weekend, I am on a Kirk Douglas marathon, starting with Paths Of Glory, before The Bad And The Beautul, Ace In The Hole, The Vikings, Lust For Le and, of course, Spartacus.Tomorrow’s Oscars will rightly honour him. We won’t see his like again.I WAS honoured to host The Millies this week.It is a wonderful event run by The Sun to salute our Armed Forces and give us all a chance to say a huge thank you.As always, there were astonishing stories of bravery, courage and self-sacrice.And as always, our lovely winners told me they were nothing special, just doing their job.I honestly don’t think they realise just how remarkable they are, or how much we owe them.One of my highlights was seeing -year-old Private Fin Doherty collect his award for inspiring others.Fin was just six when his paratrooper big brother JJ was killed in action in Afghanistan.Fin was determined to follow in JJ’s footsteps to honour his brother’s memory, and join the Parachute Regiment.He has been an outstanding addition and, in an emotional ceremony, was presented with JJ’s beret in December.Their mum Joyce admits she struggled with Fin’s decision to sign up, following the death of her eldest son.But she knew it was all Fin wanted – and she is so very proud of him.We honestly don’t deserve such an inspirational young man. But thank the Lord we have him on our side.NOTHING has changed. Phillip Schofield is exactly the same person he was before he felt the time was right to tell the world he’s gay.He’s still a loving father and husband and will still host his TV shows with consummate professionalism and skill.As Phillip said himself, you never know what people are struggling with every day and, for him, it was time to be honest with himself and everyone .I’m really glad that he has made the decision and very proud of him, although obviously it can’t have been easy.There’s been lots of tears, sleepless nights and a great deal of soul-searching. I hope he now finds peace of mind.He is a very lucky man to have a family and friends who love him very much and just want him to be happy.He also has a loyal fan base who love watching him on This Morning and that won’t change. Why would it Of course, he can expect a small number of bigots and homophobes to spew out hateful bile, but they are to be pitied and ignored.Those carping about why he took so long also need to shut up.People should be allowed to come out when it feels the right time for them.Phillip began his career at a time when being openly gay in a TV presenting role was just not an option.Thank goodness things have changed and he can be open now – and know that the overwhelmingly vast majority of us wish him and his family nothing but the very best.I was really touched by what he said about interviewing brave people on This Morning, and realising that he had to be just like them and tell his truth.Love comes in many dferent forms.Phillip and his we Stephanie adore each other and that won’t change. Again, why on earth would it At the end of his statement Phillip urged us all to be kind, especially to his family, and I hope we all take those words on board.Let’s wish them all the best and let them get on with their lives.WHAT a furore over a bare shoulder. Actress-turned-MP Tracy Brabin didn’t deserve the vitriol about her outfit but it WAS distracting.It’s unfortunate because Tracy was making important points about journalists being shut out of No  briefings – a move that makes my blood run cold and threatens Press freedom. Sadly, no one was really listening.Tracy told me she had been at a music event and didn’t expect to be back in the House. She is bemused by all the fuss.How those in public le dress should not detract from their message, be it a female MP in a low-cut top or mini-skirt, or a man wearing a gaudy tie or tight trousers.Our MPs are not known for their style and rarely make headlines for their fashion sense.I am very happy for them to keep it that way.WELL, that was a rather ill-advised memo to send, reminding local councils to fly the Union Flag on February  as a “celebration” of Prince Andrew’s birthday.I had no idea this was a “thing” and that Andrew was on a list of VIPs whose birthdays are marked with a flag waving on the roof of our town halls, instead of just cake and prosecco like the rest of us.Unsurprisingly, this ludicrous edict has caused much disgruntlement.As we know, Andrew has been booted out of The Firm by his own mum after that disastrous TV interview delving into his friendship with the American paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.Then there is the ongoing scandal over whether or not Andrew will be interviewed by the FBI as part of its investigations into child trafficking allegations against Epstein.It is all very sordid and murky. Surely even his nearest and dearest would agree this is not the time for official celebrations.He is no longer a working royal and has no place on that list.Time to lower the flags for good. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. He does not want Meghan and their son Archie to go through what he did as a child.”The Duke previously revealed in  - on the th anniversary of Princess Dianas death - that he had sought counselling at the age of  after two years of total chaos.In their first public appearance since Megxit, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex attended a summit staged by finance giant JP Morgan on Miami’s South Beach.Meghan spoke briefly about her love for her husband before introducing Harry to the stage, Page Six reports.They were spotted at the glitzy  Hotel on Thursday night with a hefty security CCTV cameras and a tarpaulin barrier. Brit taxpayers are still funding the couples protection while they live in Canada.They couple are currently searching for a new CEO of their Sussex Royal charitable foundation, and hunting for a place to spend the summer in LA, close to Meghan’s mom, Doria Ragland.Energy entrepreneur Michael Hess, the husband of Meghan’s best friend, Misha Nonoo, has already offered them a place to stay in the gated Malibu Colony, dubbed “Billionaire’s Beach.”

title: cosmic ray armenia mount aragats inside
story: The Cosmic Ray Research Station on Armenias Mount Aragats sits at an altitude of , metres - more than a third the height of Mount Everest.It is only reachable after a nine-mile hike through heavy snow and howling winds as researchers work one month on and one month off, Radio Free Europe reports.The scientists are locked in for months at a time during the gruelling winter - where temperatures can plummet to as low as -C.The base was built in  as a top-secret Soviet weapons research facility but now researchers are studying mysterious particles streaking in from space at the speed of limit.The facility is one of many sites dotted around looking at cosmic rays - and is linked to research stations as far away as Costa Rica and Indonesia.It is also equipped with sensors that can record lightning strikes from miles around.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: andrew tip caroline dont speak out
story: And then straight away I started wondering about the more important things in le such as: What shall I have for breakfast I think that she ended up in court and I have it in my mind that she pleaded not guilty.I’m also fairly sure that she’s not allowed to speak with her boyfriend until the case comes to court. But I can’t be sure, as I have other things to think about like: I need some new trousers.Then out of the blue she announced on social media that she was going to speak out because “mine and my families le is no longer up for entertainment or gossip”.“Wow,” I thought. “That’s amazing. She doesn’t know how to use apostrophes.”It turns out, however, that while she can’t write properly, she can at least think straight because she never did speak out. Which means she stopped the story from rearing up again.If only Prince Andrew was as bright. We were all dimly aware that he knew a man in America who’d had lots of sex with young girls.And that one day, this man had been found dead in a police cell. Then we went back to wonderingwe needed more washing-up liquid.Prince Andrew, however, decided that instead of letting the story die down by not saying anything, he’d go on television to set the record straight.It was a disaster. He was suddenly front-page news all over the world and he looked guilty as hell.Of what, we weren’t sure. But whatever it was, we all worked out that as he has a Bentley, he could definitely have got from a Pizza Express restaurant in Woking to the centre of London in less than six hours.A few weeks later, as the story was withering once more, Hank J Dieselburger, an American prosecutor involved in the dead sex-man’s case, announced that the FBI had received “zero co-operation” from Prince Andrew.You’d think Andrew would have learned from his earlier mistake. You’d think he’d do a Flack and say nothing.But no. The very next day, “friends” of the Prince — which is another way of saying “the Prince” — went on the attack, telling reporters he was angry and bewildered. “They haven’t even approached me — I mean him.”The problem is that ego-fed celebrities read every single thing that is written about them. And they believe everyone  is reading everything, as well.We aren’t. We don’t really care. So when you attempt to clear your name, it’s like trying to put out a fire with petrol.It’s better for Andrew, and the whole Royal Family,he takes a leaf from singer Ronan Keating’s book — “You say it best, when you say nothing atThen, perhaps, he could take a leaf from his nephew’s book. And bugger off to Canada.I’M not defending drugs here, but when you see someone giggling their way through a packet of frozen peas and some leftover sherry trle at five in the morning, it’s easy to see why someone might think: “Yes, that cannabis malarkey looks like fun. I shall give it a go.”It’s the same story with cocaine.You see a dullard finding himself absolutely fascinating at a party and you think: “I’ll have a crack at that.”But this new drug, flakka, is dferent.One man who took it ate a homeless man’s face. Another gouged her own mother’s eyes out. And a third cut off his own penis.Which raises an interesting point. Why would anyone look at someone cutting off his old fella and think, “Ooh, I’ll have what he’s having ”A BUNCH of people who think the Lake District should only be used by ramblers decided to stage a protest over plans to put ten small tourist yachts on Grasmere lake.However, before the protest could take place, the idea was abandoned. And guess what  Yup. The protest went ahead anyway.They were actually protesting about something that wasn’t going to happen. Which proves what I’ve suspected for quite some time. Ramblers aren’t entirely right in the head.Next week, they will be protesting about the sonic booms made by Concorde and the burning of witches.LAST Sunday, driving was banned in the Italian city of Milan.Who thought that was a good idea  Getting an Italian to leave his car at home is impossible. It’s a part of his being, like his liver and his lungs.Needless to say, the scheme was not very successful.So not very successful in fact that, in the first three hours, the police had issued  fines. And the authorities now admit the ban was “largely ignored”.THERE’S much talk at the moment about how internet shopping is killing the High Street. But I’m not one of the murderers.When the time comes for my annual clothes shopping trip, I simply head to the Levi’s store on Regent Street in London, point at the label on the back of the jeans I’m wearing and ask for three more pairs just the same.I love Levi’s. I’ve worn nothing  since I was  and I’ve always loved their shop, the staff have always been brilliant. They always have what I need in stock and they never ask for my phone number or email address. I’m in and out in two minutes flat.This year, though, there was a disaster. There were two disinterested youths in there who looked at the label on the back of my jeans and said, “We don’t make those any more.”WHAT  ! !On the verge of fainting with shock, I dragged them back from their interesting conversation about Stormzy and was told in an exasperated fashion that I could still buy them online.This begs a question. What’s the point of having an expensive-to-run shopyou then fill it with people who tell you to go home and buy what you need on the net PETA, an organisation for animal enthusiasts who like to wear clothes made from crude oil, have announced that people often see their pet dog as nothing more than a cheap burglar alarm.Cheap You can buy a home alarm kit these days for less than £, whereas a proper dog is going to be way more than that.Plus, you only need feed an alarm with a tiny amount of electricity to keep it running, whereas a dog requires a bed, a blanket, food, water and, later on, vets bills that will make your eyes water.THIS week, a car crashed through my fence, turning it and an expensive new gate into matchsticks.By the time I got there, the car was gone. But there was still a lot of “police aware” tape fluttering about in the breeze.So I called the nearest station, which was approximately  miles away, as I needed to contact the driver to talk about insurance. Sadly, however, while the police are “aware” of the incident, they are not prepared to give me any details.Mustn’t grumble, though. While it will cost a few hundred quid to get everything mended, I must accept that the police have much more important things to do, such as investigating dead people who weren’t paedophiles.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cops northern ireland release images brexit day bomb ira plot
story: Cops got a tip-off about a device on a lorry at Belfast docks last Friday - the day the UK left the European Union.After an extensive police search of  vehicles the bomb was found attached to a lorry in the Silverwood Industrial Estate in Lurgan, Armagh on Tuesday morning.The bomb was then made safe by disposal experts.Det Supt Sean Wright said the images released today clearly show an explosive device attached to the lorry.“They also demonstrate the sheer recklessness of those who knowingly put the driver, road users and the wider public at risk of death or serious injury, he said.It is understood the Continuity IRA planned to smuggle the bomb across the Irish sea on a ship destined for Scotland, then transport it to an unknown location in England and detonate it to coincide with Brexit.The terrorist group admitted responsibility in a statement to Belfast newspaper, the Irish News, after the Police Service Northern Irelandblamed them for the botched attack.Officers suspect the Continuity IRA chose the wrong vehicle as the trailer containing the bomb never left the estate on Friday.Det Supt Wright said the cops were continuing to appeal to anyone who was in the area of the industrial estate between pm and pm on Friday and may have noticed any unusual activity, to contact the police.He said: In addition I ask that anyone who was driving in the area and who would have dash-cam footage around these same times that they contact police, as a matter of urgency.”Seamus Leheny, from the Freight Transport Association, called the attack reckless.He said: If it was viable, it could have put the driver of the lorry and their colleagues, road users and anyone in the vicinity of the lorry in serious danger.The consequences could have been catastrophic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc change forever history comment opinion
story: From April, you, your ­neighbour and even your ancient granny will each have to cough up an extra £ a year for the honour of accessing the state broadcaster.I assume it’s the honour you’re paying for anyway. Because very often it sure as hell ain’t the product.Last Saturday, the most read piece on the BBC news homepage was a clickbait “story” — taken from Twitter — about how Kim Kardashian eats chicken nuggets.Yes, you read that right. With £.billion of your money to its name, one of the most popular “stories” on the BBC’s news website was an item which didn’t cost a penny to make, wasn’t news and stretched the definition of “public service” far beyond breaking point. And that’s just the tip of the iceberg.James Purnell — a particularly puffed-up BBC exec — announced  months ago that he and his Radio  Education team would be expanding into podcasts. He stayed horribly true to his word.In , Auntie produces podcasts on everything from football and Love Island to what Towie star Gemma ­Collins’ latest musings are, which — thanks to the big names at the helm — are ­raking in listeners.For Purnell, this is something to be celebrated. Successful podcasts presumably mean more money in his already overstuffed pockets.But for the hundreds of private podcast makers out there, it spells the beginning of the end. Competing with a company which uses public funds to net the likes of Peter Crouch is nigh-on impossible.How, I ask you, can a state broadcaster justy putting hard-working private firms out of business Yes, Ollie Williams discussing his shock exit from the Love Island villamight be entertaining, but what ­“service” is it providing the public Can the BBC — which doesn’t make Love Island — really do a better job of a Love Island podcast than ITV, which does You’d think the BBC top dogs, who are desperate to cling on to the Royal Charter, would be asking these vital questions too.But in their desperate quest for “yoof” audiences, they’ve chucked their critical faculties out of the window.And it’s all for nothing. Because the quest is a wild goose chase. According to the latest Ofcom report, most kids don’t watch ANY linear TV.So the BBC is defending a dying, analogue means of ­communication. But no one in the corporation can bear to face this unwelcome reality.So instead of cutting their own whopping salaries, they scrap well-known and well- respected current affairs ­programmes such as the ­Victoria Derbyshire show.Why  Because the more ­visible the cut, the easier it is for luvvies to pretend that the BBC is the blameless ­victim of evil Tory austerity.Nothing, of course, could be further from the truth. In fact,anything, it is the Tories and their tens of ­millions of voters who are ­victims of the BBC.The repeated Horrible Histories ­“comedy” — which mockingly undermined the existence of “British things” — and the ­ludicrously PC recent East-Enders storyline, in which a deranged killer embraces Islam and becomes a hero, are the latest in a long line of ultra- liberal BBC content seemingly designed to rub ordinary, ­patriotic Brits up the wrong way.Things can’t go on like this. If the state broadcaster is to survive, there must be an urgent and fundamental rethink.First, the BBC’s parasitical website must be shut down. The stories it features are mostly dross, or  adapted from newspaper reports.To list just one example, when Brits want to know what’s happening with Megxit, they can buy The Sun — which was responsible for the scoop in the first place.If the BBC wants a web presencethey can use it to broadcast News . Next, the salaries of fat cat managers and C-list celebs must be slashed.Then the corporation must think hard about its media offering. BBC and its often extremely niche arts offering should be folded into BBC.Radio  and , with content already well covered by ­commercial markets, must be shut down. As must every ­programme across BBC ­channels which is designed to damage ITV’s ­ratings.And of course Brits should not be punished for refusing to pay a licence fee for a service they may not use.Decriminalising it — as Boris Johnson is understood to be seriously ­considering — is the right thing to do.If Auntie can swallow a big slice of humble pie, accept her glory days are over and slim right down to size, she may have a future. If not, she’ll become a footnote to the history of British media.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
